title: In-class Exercise 2
text:
pacman::p_load(sf, tidyverse, tmap)


sg_sf <- st_read(dsn = "data", layer="CostalOutline")

Reading layer `CostalOutline' from data source 
  `C:\brigittatsai\ISSS626_AY2024-25_T1\In-class_Ex\In-class_Ex02\data' 
  using driver `ESRI Shapefile'
Simple feature collection with 60 features and 4 fields
Geometry type: POLYGON
Dimension:     XY
Bounding box:  xmin: 2663.926 ymin: 16357.98 xmax: 56047.79 ymax: 50244.03
Projected CRS: SVY21



mpsz_sf <- st_read(dsn = "data", 
                layer = "MP14_SUBZONE_WEB_PL")

Reading layer `MP14_SUBZONE_WEB_PL' from data source 
  `C:\brigittatsai\ISSS626_AY2024-25_T1\In-class_Ex\In-class_Ex02\data' 
  using driver `ESRI Shapefile'
Simple feature collection with 323 features and 15 fields
Geometry type: MULTIPOLYGON
Dimension:     XY
Bounding box:  xmin: 2667.538 ymin: 15748.72 xmax: 56396.44 ymax: 50256.33
Projected CRS: SVY21



Issue 1: Installing maptools
maptools is retired, but we can still download from CRAN archive.

install.packages("maptools",
                 repos = "https://packagemanager.posit.co/cran/2023-10-13")



Issue 2: Creating coastal outline
st_combine() returns a single, combined geometry with no resolved boundaries (returned geometries may be invalid)
if y is missing, st_union(x) returns a single geometry with resolved boundaries

sg_sf <- mpsz_sf %>%
  st_union()

title: In-class Exercise 1
text:
Load R Packages

pacman::p_load(tidyverse, sf, tmap, ggstatsplot)

::: :::


Working with Master Plan Planning Sub-zone Data
#Master Plan 2014 The code below imports shapefile

mpsz14_shp <- st_read(dsn = "data/",
                layer = "MP14_SUBZONE_WEB_PL")

Reading layer `MP14_SUBZONE_WEB_PL' from data source

  using driver `ESRI Shapefile'

to export to kml version (the original file is corrupted)

st_write(mpsz14_shp,
         "data/MP14_SUBZONE_WEB_PL.kml",
         delete_dsn = TRUE)


shp file is tidier than the kml version*

#Master Plan 2019 Subzone Boundary (No Sea)
Import the 2019 data shp file

mpsz19_shp <- st_read(dsn = "data/",
                layer = "MPSZ-2019") %>%
  st_transform(crs = 3414)

title: Hands-on Exercise 1
text:
1. Geospatial Data Science with R
Install pacman package to install and load sf and tidyverse

pacman::p_load(sf, tidyverse)

Importing polygon feature dataframe

mpsz = st_read(dsn = "data/geospatial", 
                  layer = "MP14_SUBZONE_WEB_PL")

Reading layer `MP14_SUBZONE_WEB_PL' from data source 
  `C:\brigittatsai\ISSS626_AY2024-25_T1\Hands-on_Ex\Hands-on_Ex01\data\geospatial' 
  using driver `ESRI Shapefile'
Simple feature collection with 323 features and 15 fields
Geometry type: MULTIPOLYGON
Dimension:     XY
Bounding box:  xmin: 2667.538 ymin: 15748.72 xmax: 56396.44 ymax: 50256.33
Projected CRS: SVY21


Importing polyline feature dataframe

cyclingpath = st_read(dsn = "data/geospatial", 
                         layer = "CyclingPathGazette")

Reading layer `CyclingPathGazette' from data source 
  `C:\brigittatsai\ISSS626_AY2024-25_T1\Hands-on_Ex\Hands-on_Ex01\data\geospatial' 
  using driver `ESRI Shapefile'

Geometry type: MULTILINESTRING
Dimension:     XY
Bounding box:  xmin: 11854.32 ymin: 28347.98 xmax: 42644.17 ymax: 48948.15

Geoprocessing with sf package

buffer_cycling <- st_buffer(cyclingpath, 
                               dist=5, nQuadSegs = 30)

buffer_cycling$AREA <- st_area(buffer_cycling)

sum(buffer_cycling$AREA)

2218855 [m^2]

mpsz3414$`PreSch Count`<- lengths(st_intersects(mpsz3414, preschool3414))

Calculate the density of pre-school by planning subzone

mpsz3414$Area <- mpsz3414 %>%
  st_area()

mpsz3414 <- mpsz3414 %>%
  mutate(`PreSch Density` = `PreSch Count`/Area * 1000000)

EDA and Visualization of the density of pre-school

hist(mpsz3414$`PreSch Density`)

       aes(x= as.numeric(`PreSch Density`)))+
  geom_histogram(bins=20, 
                 color="black", 
                 fill="light blue") +
  labs(title = "Are pre-school even distributed in Singapore?",
       subtitle= "There are many planning sub-zones with a single pre-school, on the other hand, \nthere are two planning sub-zones with at least 20 pre-schools",
      x = "Pre-school density (per km sq)",
      y = "Frequency")








Scatter plot

ggplot(data=mpsz3414, 
       aes(y = `PreSch Count`, 
           x= as.numeric(`PreSch Density`)))+
  geom_point(color="black", 
             fill="light blue") +
  xlim(0, 40) +
  ylim(0, 40) +
  labs(title = "",
      x = "Pre-school density (per km sq)",
      y = "Pre-school count")

Importing attribute data

popdata <- read_csv("data/aspatial/respopagesextod2011to2020.csv")

Rows: 984656 Columns: 7
── Column specification ────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
Delimiter: ","
chr (5): PA, SZ, AG, Sex, TOD
dbl (2): Pop, Time

ℹ Use `spec()` to retrieve the full column specification for this data.
ℹ Specify the column types or set `show_col_types = FALSE` to quiet this message.


Data Preparation
Data Wrangling

popdata2020 <- popdata %>%
  filter(Time == 2020) %>%
  group_by(PA, SZ, AG) %>%
  summarise(`POP` = sum(`Pop`)) %>%
  ungroup()%>%
  pivot_wider(names_from=AG, 
              values_from=POP) %>%
  mutate(YOUNG = rowSums(.[3:6])
         +rowSums(.[12])) %>%
mutate(`ECONOMY ACTIVE` = rowSums(.[7:11])+
rowSums(.[13:15]))%>%
mutate(`AGED`=rowSums(.[16:21])) %>%
mutate(`TOTAL`=rowSums(.[3:21])) %>%  
mutate(`DEPENDENCY` = (`YOUNG` + `AGED`)
/`ECONOMY ACTIVE`) %>%
  select(`PA`, `SZ`, `YOUNG`, 
       `ECONOMY ACTIVE`, `AGED`, 
       `TOTAL`, `DEPENDENCY`)

`summarise()` has grouped output by 'PA', 'SZ'. You can override using the
`.groups` argument.


Joining the attribute data and geospatial data

popdata2020 <- popdata2020 %>%
  mutate_at(.vars = vars(PA, SZ), 
          .funs = list(toupper)) %>%
  filter(`ECONOMY ACTIVE` > 0)


mpsz_pop2020 <- left_join(mpsz, popdata2020,
                          by = c("SUBZONE_N" = "SZ"))


write_rds(mpsz_pop2020, "data/mpszpop2020.rds")

Plotting a choropleth map

tmap_mode("plot")

tmap mode set to plotting

qtm(mpsz_pop2020, 
    fill = "DEPENDENCY")








Creating a choropleth map using tmap’s elements

tm_shape(mpsz_pop2020)+
  tm_fill("DEPENDENCY", 
          style = "quantile", 
          palette = "Blues",
          title = "Dependency ratio") +
  tm_layout(main.title = "Distribution of Dependency Ratio by planning subzone",
            main.title.position = "center",
            main.title.size = 1.2,
            legend.height = 0.45, 
            legend.width = 0.35,
            frame = TRUE) +

             position = c("left", "bottom"))

other available styles are: "white", "gray", "natural", "cobalt", "col_blind", "albatross", "beaver", "bw", "watercolor"

To reset style:

other available styles are: "gray", "natural", "cobalt", "col_blind", "albatross", "beaver", "bw", "classic", "watercolor" 


Create small multiple choropleth maps

tm_shape(mpsz_pop2020)+
  tm_fill(c("YOUNG", "AGED"),
          style = "equal", 
          palette = "Blues") +
  tm_layout(legend.position = c("right", "bottom")) +
  tm_borders(alpha = 0.5) +
  tmap_style("white")

tmap style set to "white"


other available styles are: "gray", "natural", "cobalt", "col_blind", "albatross", "beaver", "bw", "classic", "watercolor" 










tm_shape(mpsz_pop2020)+ 
  tm_polygons(c("DEPENDENCY","AGED"),
          style = c("equal", "quantile"), 
          palette = list("Blues","Greens")) +
  tm_layout(legend.position = c("right", "bottom"))








Defining a groupby variable

tm_shape(mpsz_pop2020) +
  tm_fill("DEPENDENCY",
          style = "quantile",
          palette = "Blues",
          thres.poly = 0) + 
  tm_facets(by="REGION_N", 
            free.coords=TRUE, 
            drop.shapes=TRUE) +
  tm_layout(legend.show = FALSE,
            title.position = c("center", "center"), 
            title.size = 20) +
  tm_borders(alpha = 0.5)

Warning: The argument drop.shapes has been renamed to drop.units, and is
therefore deprecated









Multiple stand-alone maps

youngmap <- tm_shape(mpsz_pop2020)+ 
  tm_polygons("YOUNG", 
              style = "quantile", 
              palette = "Blues")

agedmap <- tm_shape(mpsz_pop2020)+ 
  tm_polygons("AGED", 
              style = "quantile", 
              palette = "Blues")

tmap_arrange(youngmap, agedmap, asp=1, ncol=2)








Mapping spatial object meeting a selecion criterion

tm_shape(mpsz_pop2020[mpsz_pop2020$REGION_N=="CENTRAL REGION", ])+
  tm_fill("DEPENDENCY", 
          style = "quantile", 
          palette = "Blues", 
          legend.hist = TRUE, 
          legend.is.portrait = TRUE,
          legend.hist.z = 0.1) +
  tm_layout(legend.outside = TRUE,
            legend.height = 0.45, 
            legend.width = 5.0,
            legend.position = c("right", "bottom"),
            frame = FALSE) +
  tm_borders(alpha = 0.5)

gm$shape.orig_crs): legend.width controls the width of the legend within a map.

bw

298.4095

plot(kde_childcareSG_adaptive, main = "Adaptive bandwidth")

Compare KDE of childcare at Ponggol, Tampines, Choa Chu Kang and Jurong West planning areas.


Extract target planning areas

pg <- mpsz_sf %>%
  filter(PLN_AREA_N == "PUNGGOL")
tm <- mpsz_sf %>%
  filter(PLN_AREA_N == "TAMPINES")
ck <- mpsz_sf %>%
  filter(PLN_AREA_N == "CHOA CHU KANG")
jw <- mpsz_sf %>%
  filter(PLN_AREA_N == "JURONG WEST")

Plot the target planning areas

all












Convert sf objects into owin objects that is required by spatstat

pg_owin = as.owin(pg)
tm_owin = as.owin(tm)
ck_owin = as.owin(ck)
jw_owin = as.owin(jw)




Extract childcare that is within the specific region

childcare_pg_ppp = childcare_ppp_jit[pg_owin]
childcare_tm_ppp = childcare_ppp_jit[tm_owin]
childcare_ck_ppp = childcare_ppp_jit[ck_owin]
childcare_jw_ppp = childcare_ppp_jit[jw_owin]

rescale.ppp() function used to transform unit of measurement from metre to kilometre

childcare_pg_ppp.km = rescale.ppp(childcare_pg_ppp, 1000, "km")
childcare_tm_ppp.km = rescale.ppp(childcare_tm_ppp, 1000, "km")
childcare_ck_ppp.km = rescale.ppp(childcare_ck_ppp, 1000, "km")
childcare_jw_ppp.km = rescale.ppp(childcare_jw_ppp, 1000, "km")

Plot the 4 study areas and the locations of the childcare centre

Perform the Clark-Evans test of aggregation for a spatial point pattern by using clarkevans.test() of statspat.
H0 = The distribution of childcare services are randomly distributed
H1 = The distribution of childcare services are not randomly distributed
95% confidence interval will be used



clarkevans.test(childcareSG_ppp,
                correction="none",
                clipregion="sg_owin",
                alternative=c("clustered"),
                nsim=99)


    Clark-Evans test
    No edge correction
    Z-test

data:  childcareSG_ppp
R = 0.55631, p-value < 2.2e-16
alternative hypothesis: clustered (R < 1)


Null hypothesis is rejected because the distribution is clustered and not randomly distributed




clarkevans.test(childcare_ck_ppp,
                correction="none",
                clipregion=NULL,
                alternative=c("two.sided"),
                nsim=999)


    Clark-Evans test
    No edge correction
    Z-test

data:  childcare_ck_ppp
R = 0.92258, p-value = 0.2473
alternative hypothesis: two-sided






clarkevans.test(childcare_tm_ppp,
                correction="none",
                clipregion=NULL,
                alternative=c("two.sided"),
                nsim=999)


    Clark-Evans test
    No edge correction
    Z-test

data:  childcare_tm_ppp
R = 0.79864, p-value = 0.0002789
alternative hypothesis: two-sided

title: Hands-on Exercise 2
section: Analysing Spatial Point Process Using K-Function
text:
Analysing Spatial Point Process Using K-Function
Computed using Kest() of spatstat package

Choa Chu Kang planning area

Computing K-function estimate

K_ck = Kest(childcare_ck_ppp, correction = "Ripley")
plot(K_ck, . -r ~ r, ylab= "K(d)-r", xlab = "d(m)")










Performing Complete Spatial Randomness Test
Ho = The distribution of childcare services at Choa Chu Kang are randomly distributed.
H1= The distribution of childcare services at Choa Chu Kang are not randomly distributed.
The null hypothesis will be rejected if p-value is smaller than alpha value of 0.001.

K_ck.csr <- envelope(childcare_ck_ppp, Kest, nsim = 99, rank = 1, glocal=TRUE)
